B." Watson''' (July 10, 1953 – September 28, 2013) was an American [[country music]] artist. He charted in 1991 with the single "Light at the End of the Tunnel" from his album of the same name. ==Biography== Haskell Burl Watson was born July 10, 1953, in [[Tyler, Texas]], and raised in [[La Porte, Texas]]. His nickname "B. B." stood for "Bad Boy".{{cite book|last=Whitburn|first=Joel|title=Hot Country Songs 1944 to 2017|publisher=Record Research, Inc|year=2017|pages=385|isbn=978-0-89820-229-8}} Watson spent his teenage and young adult years working as a musician throughout Texas before moving to [[Nashville, Tennessee]], in 1991 to begin a music career. That same year, he was the first act signed to [[BNA Records]], then a new label division of [[RCA Records Nashville]]. His debut single "Light at the End of the Tunnel" was the label's first charted single, entering ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'' [[Hot Country Songs]] in mid-1991.{{cite news | url=https://www.newspapers.com/image/220438997 | title=Watson nets Crawdads as backup | work=The Times | date=October 18, 1991 | accessdate=February 17, 2023 | pages=11C}} The song peaked at number 23 that year. Another single, "Lover Not a Fighter", peaked at number 43. Both songs were included on his only BNA album, also titled ''Light at the End of the Tunnel''. Nick Cristiano of ''[[The Philadelphia Inquirer]]'' rated the album three out of four stars, comparing Watson's style favorably to [[Merle Haggard]].{{cite news | url=https://www.newspapers.com/image/175681600/ | title=Remembering Big Star; Mozart Quartets; B.B. Watson | work=The Philadelphia Inquirer | date=March 15, 1992 | accessdate=February 17, 2023 | pages=N10}} Michael McCall of ''[[Country Music (magazine)|Country Music]]'' magazine praised the album's [[honky-tonk]] sound and Watson's "big voice".{{cite journal | url=https://worldradiohistory.com/Archive-All-Music/Country-Music/90s/Country-Music-1992-01-02.pdf | title=Record reviews | author=Michael McCall | journal=Country Music | pages=19 | date=February 2, 1992}} His only other release was 2001's ''Delta Dream'', which charted the single "The Memory Is the Last Thing to Go" that year. Watson died in [[Baytown, Texas]], on September 28, 2013.{{cite web|url=http://hosting-22185.tributes.com/show/Haskell-B-B-Watson-96466949|title=Haskell BB Watson – Crespo & Jirrels Funeral & Cremation Services|date=September 2, 2013|accessdate=December 30, 2013}} ==Discography== ===Albums=== {| class="wikitable plainrowheaders" style="text-align:center;" |- ! style="width:16em;"| Title ! style="width:20em;"| Album details |- ! scope="row"| ''Light at the End of the Tunnel'' | * Release date: September 24, 1991 * Label: [[BNA Records]] |- ! scope="row"| ''Delta Dream'' | * Release date: June 12, 2001 * Label: Oarfin Records |} ===Singles=== {| class="wikitable plainrowheaders" style="text-align:center;" |- ! rowspan="2"| Year ! rowspan="2" style="width:20em;"| Single ! colspan="2"| Peak chart
